The impact of a Fourier transform \\( F(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-i\\omega t} z(t) dt \\) on z(t) is considered.

If at some point \\( t_1 \\< T \\), a Laplace transform \\( Lp(z) = \\int_{0}^{\\infty} e^{-st} z(t) dt \\) (where s is a complex constant) is applied as an intervention, will the endpoint \\( z(T) \\) mainly depend on the operator \\( L \\), and not significantly on the effects of \\( F(z) \\) or \\( Lp(z) \\)?
Explanation: The Laplace transform as an intervention alters the state \\( z(t) \\) at \\( t_1 \\) by transforming it in a manner different from\\( F(z) \\), affecting all subsequent evolution under \\( Lz \\). Therefore, \\( z(T) \\) becomes a function of the applied Laplace and Fourier transforms along with the operator L, making it dependent on all factors.
